awd_titl_txt: RUI: In situ Characterization of Competitively Balanced Supramolecular and Biomolecular Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Douglas Vander Griend at Calvin University is working with undergraduate students, including some that are incarcerated, to study how molecules work together and assemble themselves. Whether in the human body or in new technology, molecules combine to make ensembles, but these complex structures also make the materials hard to characterize. To conquer the difficult task of figuring out how an entire ensemble of molecules behaves, Professor Douglas Vander Griend and his group use computers with advanced mathematics to model all the molecular interactions simultaneously. The research project provides undergraduate students with an opportunity to conduct hands-on chemical research. Professor Vander Griend is also making his analysis tools available via the web at Sivvu.org to assist other labs in studying similar problems. 

Professor Vander Griend is researching how supramolecular systems with multiple competitive arrangements can be effectively characterized in situ so that they can be further tailored for specific mechanical, chemical and biological tasks. The key is using advanced mathematical modeling to achieve understanding in the characterization of complicated solution mixtures. The three chosen systems (β-hairpin peptide folding, Ni(II) discrete coordination networks, and transition metal acetate coordination clusters) exemplify increasingly complicated aspects of solution-phase chemistry in which multiple arrangements of molecules exist in equilibrium with each other. The detailed insight into the thermodynamics of such ‘messy’ systems bolsters scientists’ ability to organize, characterize, and optimize ensembles of molecules. Besides the scientific merit of these pursuits, this research helps prepare undergraduates, including prison inmates in the State of Michigan, for careers in scientific research.  The research team also enables expert modeling and archiving of spectrophotometric titration data from labs around the world through websites, consultations, short courses, and peer-reviewed publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Molecules do some of their best work as ensembles—all the parts of a thing taken together so that each part is considered only in relation to the whole. Whether nanomachines or artificial enzymes, the ability to organize, characterize, and optimize increasingly complex systems is paramount to the advancement of science (Figure 1). This is why chemistry continues to be central in the development of functional materials.

Since 2018, the Vander Griend lab has continued to study many different complex systems of molecules. During this time 16 undergraduate researchers, 5 undergraduate programmers, and 5 prison inmates have been trained to contribute to our ongoing effort to thermodynamically characterize a wide variety of chemical systems. Students master numerous lab skills and data analysis techniques, as well as learning to communicate scientifically to a global audience.

With the money from this NSF grant we have published 11 peer-reviewed journal articles (7 with undergraduate co-authors), prepared 38 research presentations for various local, regional, national and international conferences, and led 3 workshops on the quantification of binding constants.

Some of our work focuses on methodology, which means designing new and better ways to go about characterizing complex systems by quantifying the binding constants for all the chemical reactions that happen (Figure 2). We then demonstrate and teach this approach to other labs so that they can best quantify the binding constants of the chemical systems that they study. More and more we are convincing people not to take the unnecessary short cuts that lead to poor understanding of their systems. We now have all the mathematical and computational insight to do it right. This is what our workshops focus on.

We also support numerous collaborators around the country and the world. Graduate labs at Indiana University, MIT, the University of Oregon, the University of California – Riverside, and the Università della Svizzera italiana, Lugano, Switzerland all rely on our expertise. They study intriguing systems that defy classic purification and characterization techniques, so our approach has been key to their success.

Finally, we also study our systems of our own choosing. My lab at Calvin University examined the replicability of the thermodynamic modeling of spectroscopic titration data in the nickel(II) en system (Figure 3). This work featured six replicate titrations carried out by an autotitrating robot and established the importance of both experimental replicates and bootstrapping to ascertain the true confidence intervals for the binding constants. My lab also discovered what we call the suprachelate effect: where monodenticity can overtake multidenticity of ligands. This is especially applicable when using bidentate ligands such as ethylenediamine to create supramolecular assemblies (Figure 4). Most recently, we explored the incisive question of how to detect false positives and false negatives in a 1:1 binding study. We focused on the mini-Gs G-protein (Figure 5). We conducted 25 spectrophotometric titrations of various substrates and drug molecules, finding that various statistical tools were necessary to weed out false positives for binding.

Underlying this work is the computer program SIVVU that was developed in the Vander Griend lab. It is now available to the world through the website Sivvu.org, which allows anyone with internet access to upload spectroscopic titration data and model it for themselves using the same advanced calculations that we use. Extensive visual feedback allows the user to evaluate their models thoroughly. The website ports the larger computational jobs required for bootstrapping to the NSF-supported Borg supercluster here at Calvin university. At this point hundreds of users have accounts at SIVVU.org.

NSF funding through this grant has been crucial to all these accomplishments and impacts. There has been so much valuable science done leading to enhanced understanding that benefits so many researchers. Along the way many students have been mentored in research and are now more poised than ever to impact the world with their passion, intellect, and skill for science.
